ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Ototoxicity (Amikacin-induced)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Significant bilateral threshold shifts in high and ultra-high frequencies compared to baseline, coinciding with high-dose amikacin treatment.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Monitor standard frequency thresholds (250-8000 Hz) for changes compared to baseline.
Monitor ultra-high frequencies (9000-20000 Hz), which are typically the first to show ototoxic damage.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient exhibits normal hearing in the low-to-mid frequencies but significant bilateral sensorineural hearing loss in the high and ultra-high frequencies. Comparison with baseline reveals substantial threshold shifts consistent with amikacin ototoxicity. Speech recognition remains excellent in quiet.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear normal 250-4000 Hz, sloping to moderate SNHL at 6000-8000 Hz. Left ear normal 250-6000 Hz, mild SNHL at 8000 Hz. Significant shifts from baseline: Right ear decreased 35 dB at 6000 Hz and 45 dB at 8000 Hz; Left ear decreased 40 dB at 8000 Hz.

tests.name: High-frequency audiometry
tests.result_summary: Moderate to moderately severe loss 9000-14000 Hz bilaterally; no response 16000-20000 Hz. Significant shifts from baseline (e.g., 20-35 dB decreases across 9000-11200 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT Right 2 dB HL, Left -2 dB HL. WRS Right 100%, Left 96% at 50 dB HL.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral and contralateral thresholds WNL 500-4000 Hz, except Left contralateral elevated at 500 Hz. Reflex decay negative.

proposed_items: Consult with prescribing physician to switch antibiotic
counseling_actions: Discuss significant high-frequency hearing changes linked to medication
Explain the need to coordinate with the physician for potential medication change
Recommend hearing protection in loud environments

escalation.rationale_short: Significant ototoxic threshold shift requires immediate medical review to consider alternative treatment and prevent further loss.

expected_outcome: Physicians switched the patient from amikacin to another antibiotic due to hearing loss and lack of lung infection improvement.
Hearing was tested 1 month later and was stable.
